verses.text: Observe, my child, the commands of your father, do not abandon your mother’s instruction.
Bind them onto your heart forever; hang them round about your neck.
When you walk, Wisdom will guide you; when you lie down, she will watch you; when you wake up, she will talk with you.
For precept illumines, instruction enlightens, and reproof that disciplines leads to life,
Preserving you safe from the wife of another, from the slippery tongue of the stranger.
Do not long in your heart for her beauty. Do not be caught by her eyes.
For, while harlotry costs but a morsel of bread, ’Tis the precious life the adulteress hunts.
Can a man take fire in his bosom without his clothes being burned?
Or on glowing coals can he walk without his feet being scorched?
So with him that approaches his neighbour’s wife: no one that touches her ever may go unpunished.
Do people not despise a thief, When he steals even to satisfy hunger?
When caught, he must pay seven-fold. And give all that his house contains.
But the adulterer is witless: he destroyes himself by his doings.
For stripes and disgrace will be his, And a shame that will never be blotted.
For jealousy maddens a man; in the day of revenge he is pitiless.
He will accept no ransom, nor will gifts in profusion content him.
My son if you have gone bail for your neighbour, and given your pledge for another;
if by your own lips you are snared, and are trapped by the words of your mouth:
then this do, my son, and free yourself, since you have come into his power. Go, stir youself, besiege your neighbour;
give no sleep to your eyes. nor slumber to your eyelids,
shake yourself free, like a roe, from the snare, or a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise,
without officer, ruler, or chief,
she provides her bread in the summer. and gathers her food in the harvest.
How long will you lie, O sluggard? When will you rise from your sleep?
“Just a little more sleep, a little more slumber, a little more lying with folded hands.”
So will poverty come on you like a robber, and want like an armed man.
Sunk in wickedness is the man whose speech is ingrained with falsehood –
who winks his eyes, or shuffles his feet, or makes signs with his fingers,
gives his mind to the planning of mischief, and always is scattering discord.
For these things will sudden disaster assail him; he will swiftly be crushed beyond all hope of healing.
Six things there are which the Lord detests, yes, seven does He abhor:
haughty eyes, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood,
a mind that plans wicked devices, and feet that are swift to do wrong,
a false witness that utters lies, One that scatters strife among brethren.
